overview_of_class:
Theories and intervention principles for disorders of oral language, reading, written language, mathematics, and nonverbal learning.
GENERAL OUTLINE AND UNITS OF THE COURSE
I. Definitions, principles of assessment, theoretical perspectives, and legal issues.
II. Approaches to instruction.
III. Disorders of oral language (listening and speaking).
IV. Disorders of reading (decoding and comprehension).
V. Disorders of written language.
VI. Disorders of mathematics.
VII. Nonverbal disabilities and social skills.
VIII. Approaches to progress monitoring and service delivery: implications for accommodations, instruction, and transition to higher education and the world of work.
IX. Long term outlook and prognosis, follow-up studies, psychosocial, educational, and vocational needs.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. To be able to summarize the symptoms of LD that one might observe across the life span.
2. To be able to list and discuss the significance of several components of the LD definition.
3. To be able to compare and contrast a discrepancy model with other approaches used to identify children and adults with learning disabilities.
4. To be able to do an analysis of tasks and tests using the theoretical constructs discussed in class.
5. To be able to define and summarize several principles of clinical teaching and other types of instruction (e.g. Direct Instruction).
6. To be able to list types of accommodations that can be provided.
7. To be able to summarize instructional principles for various types of learning disabilities.
8. To be able to summarize results of long-term studies.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
BROAD GOALS:
To gain an understanding of learning disabilities and the heterogeneity within the population.
To become familiar with the symptomatology across the life span.
To become familiar with general theoretical perspectives which are used in the field.
To understand the principles of assessment and differential diagnosis.
To understand several theoretical constructs (schema) on which diagnosis and intervention can be based. Emphasis will be given to clinical teaching.
To become familiar with areas of learning that should be considered in a psychoeducational evaluation and to understand types of assessment that can be used for eligibility and intervention.
To become aware of relationships between various learning problems and clusters of disorders that co-occur.
To be able to generate hypotheses about the meaning of success and error patterns within each area of achievement.
To understand principles, procedures, and techniques for instruction and accommodations that may be needed for specific types of learning disabilities.
To understand the types of services and delivery systems used in schools.
To understand the need for various types of progress monitoring.
To understand possible long-term needs and outcomes, including risk and resilience.
